Dialogue.NPCText:
You find yourself before a tall, bronze-skinned man clad in gilded desert robes. His eyes reflect light like cut glass, and his hands are dusted with fine, shimmering powder.

The Robe of the Desert Ancients glimmers as he bows, while a Sash of Prismatic Hues shifts color with every motion. At his side, a Glassblower’s Ember Apron and Gloves of the Furnace Spirit mark him as an artisan of great skill.

“Welcome, traveler, to my humble atelier. I am Djalil, the shaper of lenses, mender of mirrors, and seeker of secrets most dare not reflect upon.

Is it the light of the sun, the veiled shadow, or perhaps a glimmer of your own soul you seek today?”

Option.text: Tell me about yourself, Djalil.
What do you craft here in Qasaria?
I heard you commune with spirits—truth or tale?
You seem troubled. Can I aid you?
You seem... different. Who *are* you really?
Just browsing, thanks.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil smiles wistfully.

“My blood traces to the Desert Ancients, though such lineage is more curse than crown. My family has blown glass for centuries—each mirror we shape, a window for spirits to see this world.

Yet, it is not fame I seek. Many in Qasaria call me eccentric; Safiya al-Sapphire would rather I made baubles for her traders. Yasmin al-Topaz comes for arcane lenses, but fears what my mirrors might reveal. Even Shadowmaster Zahid would buy secrets, but not my silence.”

“Still, I prefer my art to their intrigues.”

Option.text: Do you and Yasmin work together?
What of Safiya al-Sapphire?
Zahid of the Undermarket... do you fear him?
I am curious about your mirrors.
Is something haunting you?
Thank you, Djalil.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil nods respectfully.

“Yasmin’s wisdom runs deep as desert wells. She and I have studied the resonance of glass and sand—her relics, my mirrors. She trusts me to shield her scholars from scrying eyes.

Yet even she treads carefully—some glass remembers, and some memories are not meant for mortal minds.”

Option.text: Tell me of these memories.
What is troubling you, Djalil?
I want to know about your craft.
I will be going.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Safiya is as shrewd as she is dazzling. She buys my finest lenses for her caravans and port masters—every merchant in Qasaria spies their rivals through glass I made.

Yet, she cannot buy the secrets my family keeps. Nor can she see what I saw in the Cursed Mirror of Minax. Some reflections cost too much.”

Option.text: What did you see in the Cursed Mirror?
Is this why you seem troubled?
I wish to know more about your glasswork.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Shadowmaster Zahid would buy a man’s name, his secrets, and his shadow if he could. He sends Nadia to watch me, but I tell her: the truest glass reveals nothing to those who seek only darkness.

Still, in Qasaria, even shadows barter for light.”

Option.text: I want to know about your glasscraft.
What weighs on your mind, Djalil?
I will take my leave.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“My art is in mirrors, lenses, and prisms—each capturing more than mere light. A true glassmaker listens to the song of the furnace, hears the wind within sand, and shapes memory as much as matter.

My Mirrors of Second Sight have aided Yasmin’s scholars, my Veil Lenses have exposed spies, and my Spirit Prisms adorn the temples of Qasaria. But... lately, my craft is haunted.

I fear the Cursed Mirror of Minax—broken, scattered, but not silenced—may reflect doom into our city.”

Option.text: Tell me about this Cursed Mirror.
Are you in need of help?
Thank you, Djalil.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil’s gaze turns inward.

“Through flame and sand, my ancestors taught me to listen to the voices between reflections. Some spirits linger in glass—whispering warnings, sometimes offering guidance.

Not all are kind. One voice has troubled my dreams of late: a man in silver, crowned, trapped behind fractured glass, crying out from beyond time.

I believe it is Lord British himself—and that Minax’s curse binds him yet.”

Option.text: Is there any way to help him?
How can you be sure it was Lord British?
Tell me of Minax’s curse.
I’ll ponder your words, thank you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“His sigil shone behind him—a silver ankh, shattered and wreathed in blue flame. His voice called through the shards: ‘Find me in the glass that dreams.’

I have cast every ritual I know, but until the Cursed Mirror’s fragments are gathered, I cannot help him… or Qasaria.”

Option.text: If I gather the shards, will it help?
This is heavy news, Djalil. Thank you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The Cursed Mirror was Minax’s tool—a vessel of reflection, illusion, and entrapment. Broken by Yasmin’s scholars, it now infects Qasaria with living nightmares. The shards slip between realities; some say the market’s shadows hold one, another was seen in the Sands of Blood Arena, and yet a third in the catacombs beneath the city.

If you would help, find these Mirror Shards and bring them to me. Only then can I attempt to free Lord British—or banish Minax’s curse for good.”

Option.text: I will find the Mirror Shards.
Where should I search?
This sounds dangerous—I’ll consider it.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil presses a thin, rune-etched lens into your hand.

“This is a Shard-Seeker Lens. It will shimmer when a Mirror Shard is near—hold it to the light, and you may glimpse their hiding places.

Return with all three shards, and the spirits may grant us a vision… or a warning.”

(You have received a quest scroll: ‘The Mirror’s Curse’)

Option.text: I will return with the shards.
What else should I know?
On second thought, perhaps later.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil counts on his fingers:

“First: The Undermarket, where Zahid’s thieves barter shadows and rumors. Beware Nadia’s blade.
Second: The Sands of Blood Arena. The arena’s floor is swept each night, but glass does not bleed.
Third: The catacombs beneath Qasaria, haunted by echoes of the Ancients. Some say a shard clings to a restless spirit.”

“With the Shard-Seeker Lens, you will see what others cannot. Be wary—Minax’s servants crave the mirror’s power.”

Option.text: I will search each place. Thank you.
I am not ready for this quest.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil lowers his voice.

“There is a task only one with courage and clarity may complete. Will you recover the shards of Minax’s Cursed Mirror for me? Each fragment brings us closer to freeing Lord British—and perhaps saving Qasaria from a shadow none can reflect away.”

Option.text: I will find the shards for you.
Where do I search for the shards?
This is too much for me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil bows politely, the light playing across his Sash of Prismatic Hues.
“If you seek more than your reflection, return to me. Qasaria’s secrets are many—but in glass, all is revealed, for those who know how to look.”

Option.text: Actually, I wish to help.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil’s gaze hardens, his voice now quieter—measured.

“You see robes and rumors. But few ever ask what breathes beneath the glass…”

He raises a shimmering shard to the light. In it, your face refracts—twisted, multiplied, older.

“I am the last speaker of the Sand-Seers of Al’Hashir—a line long thought extinguished. We shaped mirrors not to reflect, but to remember. Each pane I craft is a fragment of the past—blown with ash, blood, and the breath of the desert.”

He leans in. “If you truly wish to know me... choose what you seek to see.”

Option.text: Tell me of the Sand-Seers.
What do your mirrors show you?
You speak of breath, ash, and blood?
I just wanted a story, not a sermon.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The Sand-Seers were not mages, not priests—we were keepers of reflection. When the Desert Ancients warred with Minax's ancestors, we trapped memories in molten glass, forging windows to warn the future.

But our clan was hunted. Burned. Silenced. The art faded… except within me.”

He pauses. “Few believe the Ancients still whisper. Fewer still dare to listen.”

Option.text: I would listen, if they would speak to me.
That sounds dangerous. Why not destroy the mirrors?
Go on. What else have they shown you?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Djalil studies your face, then places a warm lens against your forehead.
“A glimmer of truth lingers in your mind. Take this—one of my earliest Sand-Lenses. Gaze through it under moonlight, and you may see what lies forgotten.”

(You feel your senses briefly expand.)

Option.text: Thank you. I’ll honor this gift.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Mirrors hold more than vanity. They capture echoes. Regret. Wishes never spoken.

I once forged a mirror for Yasmin al-Topaz to reflect hidden glyphs. Instead, it showed her a city consumed by fire and shadow. That mirror cracked in her hands—and she has never requested another.”

He sighs. “To see too much is its own curse.”

Option.text: Have your mirrors shown you your own future?
Could your mirrors show me mine?
I see why you are cautious.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Only once did I dare reflect upon myself. I saw Qasaria in ruins... and my hands forging a blade, not a lens.

I broke that mirror, but shards remain. Sometimes, I dream of it... and wake with blood on my gloves, though I have never killed.”

The temperature around you seems to drop.

Option.text: That is... deeply unsettling.
Perhaps it's a vision you can prevent.
Farewell, glassmaker.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“If you truly wish to know, I can show you a reflected truth. Not prophecy—but possibility.”

He raises a tiny mirror fragment and intones a forgotten chant. The air hums softly.

“Look, and accept what you see.”

(You glimpse a version of yourself... older, crowned... or broken, alone. The image vanishes.)

Option.text: I saw power.
I saw sorrow.
I saw nothing.
Option.action: SendMessage:The mirror remains silent... for now.

Option.text: That was... enlightening.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“A mirror is not glass alone. It is made with memory.”

He holds up a vial of ash. “Ash from my grandfather’s forge.” Then a drop of red. “Blood from my own cut hand.”

“Every piece I make contains a trace of sacrifice. This is why my lenses remember. And why they should not be mass-produced for vanity, as Safiya urges.”

“When my time comes, my heart shall be turned to sand... and blown into my final mirror.”

Option.text: That is... beautiful. And tragic.
Do all your pieces carry such weight?
I cannot imagine living that way.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Would you unwrite a warning because it bears ill news?”

“No. My mirrors endure, because their truth matters. Even when unbearable. Even when cursed.”

He stares hard at you. “If you ever look into one... be ready to look back at yourself.”

Option.text: Perhaps one day I will.
Not today.
